column1: Vukovar (Serbo-Croatian pronunciation: [ʋûkoʋaːr]; Serbian Cyrillic: Вуковар) is a city in eastern Croatia. It contains Croatia's largest river port
column2: located at the confluence of the Vuka and the Danube. Vukovar is the seat of Vukovar-Syrmia County. The city's registered population was 26
column3: 468 in the 2011 census
column4: with a total of 27
column5: 683 in the municipality.

column1: The name Vukovar means 'town on the Vuka River' (Vuko from the Vuka River
column2: and vár from the Hungarian word for 'fortress'). The river was called "Ulca" in antiquity
column3: probably from an Illyrian language. Its name might be related to the name of the river "Volga". Folk etymology has connected it to the Croatian word "vuk"
column4: meaning "wolf". In other languages
column5: the city in German is known as Wukowar and in Hungarian as Vukovár or Valkóvár. In the late 17th century
column6: the medieval Croatian name Vukovo was supplanted by the Hungarian Vukovár.

column1: Vukovar is located in the Eastern part of the Republic of Croatia and is the centre of the Vukovar-Syrmia County. Its location places it at the border of historical provinces Eastern Slavonia and Western Syrmia.
The city is positioned on important transport routes. Since time immemorial transport routes from the northwest to the southeast were active in the Danube Valley through the Vukovar area.
After steam ships were introduced in the mid-19th century
column2: and with the arrival of present-day tourist ships
column3: Vukovar is connected with Budapest and Vienna upstream and all the way to Romania downstream. The Vukovar harbour is an important import and export station. The Danube has always been and remains the connection of the people of Vukovar with Europe and the world.

column1: Vukovar is located 20 km (12 mi) northeast of Vinkovci and 36 km (22 mi) southeast of Osijek
column2: with an elevation of 108 m (354 ft). Vukovar is located on the main road D2 Osijek—Vukovar—Ilok and on the Vinkovci—Vukovar railway (and road D55).

column1: One Scordisci archaeological site in Vukovar dating back to late La Tène culture was excavated in the 1970s and 1980s as a part of rescue excavations in eastern Croatia. Archaeological site was a part of the settlement network of Scordisci in the area of Vinkovci.
Slavic tribes settled in this area in the 6th century. In the 9th century the region was part of the Slavic Balaton Principality ruled by prince Pribina
column2: part of the Principality of Pannonian Croatia ruled by prince Ljudevit
column3: and part of the Bulgarian Empire. In the 11th–12th century
column4: the region was part of the Kingdom of Croatia; from the 13th to 16th century part of the Kingdom of Hungary; and between 1526-1687 under Ottoman rule.

column1: Vukovar was mentioned first in the 13th century as Volko
column2: Walk
column3: Wolkov (original Croatian/Slavic name of the town was Vukovo). In 1231
column4: Vukovo obtained its first privileges and later the right to levy taxes on passages along the Danube and the Vuka. During administration of the medieval Kingdom of Hungary
column5: the town was a seat of Valkó (Croatian: Vuka) county
column6: which was located between the Drava and Sava rivers
column7: while during Ottoman administration it was part of the Sanjak of Syrmia. At the end of the 17th century

column1: After the Treaty of Karlowitz in 1699
column2: Vukovar was part of the Habsburg Monarchy
column3: Slavonia (Transleithania after the compromise of 1867)
column4: and soon after in the Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia
column5: created when the Kingdom of Slavonia and the Kingdom of Croatia were merged in 1868.

column1: In the late 19th and early 20th century
column2: Vukovar was the seat of Syrmia County of the Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia.
Vukovar became part of the newly formed Kingdom of Serbs
column3: Croats
column4: and Slovenes (Yugoslavia in 1929). Between 1918 and 1922
column5: Vukovar was the administrative seat of the county of Syrmia (Srijem)
column6: and between 1922 and 1929 it was the administrative seat of Syrmia oblast. After 1929
column7: Vukovar was part of the Sava Banovina
column8: and beginning in 1939 it was part of the Banovina of Croatia. Between 1941 and 1944
column9: Vukovar was part of the Independent State of Croatia. During World War II the city was bombed by the Allies. In 2008 an unexploded bomb was found in the city from this period. From 1945
column10: it was part of the People's Republic of Croatia within the new Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

column1: After the creation of the Kingdom of Serbs
column2: Croats and Slovenes and in the wake of communism gaining popularity throughout Europe
column3: Vukovar became the location where in 1920 the Socialist Labor Party of Yugoslavia (Communists) (Socijalistička radnička partija Jugoslavije - komunista) was renamed the Communist Party of Yugoslavia (Komunistička partija Jugoslavije).

column1: Vukovar was heavily damaged during the Croatian War of Independence. Approximately 1
column2: 800 self-organised defenders (the army of Croatia was still in its infancy at this time) defended the city for 87 days against approximately 36
column3: 000 troops of the Serb-dominated JNA supplemented with 110 vehicles and tanks and dozens of planes. The city suffered heavy damage during the siege and was eventually overrun. It is estimated that 1
column4: 800 defenders of Vukovar and civilians were killed
column5: 800 went missing and 22
column6: 000 civilians were forced into exile.The damage to Vukovar during the siege has been called the worst in Europe since World War II
column7: drawing comparisons with Stalingrad. The city's water tower
column9: was retained by city planners to serve as a testimony to the events of the early 1990s.

column2: 000 people from all over the country gathered in Vukovar for the 15th anniversary of the fall of the city to commemorate those who were killed during the siege. A museum dedicated to the siege was opened in the basement of a now rebuilt hospital that had been damaged during the battle. On 27 September 2007 the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia convicted two former JNA officers
column3: Mile Mrkšić and Veselin Šljivančanin for their involvement in the Vukovar massacre.As a result of the conflict
column4: a deep ethnic divide exists between the Croat and Serb populations.

column1: In the years from 1948 until 1991 Vukovar's population increased quickly due to industrial development. Primarily it was immigration that fed the growth in the Vukovar region and in the town particularly. The region's population distribution changed notably too when the town of Ilok became the second largest town in the region.

The most significant change was the forced displacement and internment of the German civilian population after World War II. The confiscated houses and properties were given to Croat and Serb colonists during the years of Socialist Yugoslavia.
The Croats were in the majority in most villages and in the region's eastern part
column2: whereas the Serbs dominated in the northwest. Vukovar's population was ethnically mixed and had 28 ethnic groups before the war. Since the boundaries of the municipality have changed a few times
column3: there are significant differences in the population census between '61 and '71
column4: and '91 and '01.

column1: Particularly since the war in Croatia
column2: much of the native Croat population has moved to other areas of Croatia or emigrated to Western Europe (notably Germany or Austria) and many Serbs have either moved to Serbia or to Canada and Western Europe.

column3: the city's ethnic makeup showed equal percentages of Croat and Serb residents. The city remains very divided
column4: as a deeper sense of reconciliation has failed to take root. The ethnic communities remain separated by mistrust
column5: divided institutions and disappointment. Separate schooling for Croat and Serb children remains in place. Incidents involving Croats and Serbs occur regularly
column6: and public spaces have become identified not by the services they offer but by the ethnicity of those who gather there. Even coffee shops are identified as Croat or Serb.In 2013
column7: the government's intention to implement in Vukovar the Constitutional Law on the Rights of Ethnic Minorities in Croatia that allowed for minorities
column8: where they made up more than a third of a city's population
column9: to be entitled to have their language used for official purposes

column1: In Vukovar during the year there are many cultural events. Certainly the most important is the Danube region Vukovar Film Festival.

The Vukovar Film Festival is unique due to many things. It is the only film festival of the community of Danube region countries and the only one held literally on the Danube. It is designed to promote and spread the creative development of filmmakers from the region and it is organised with the intent to contribute to cultural restoration in the city destroyed in the Homeland War. The theme of the festival
column2: the films from the Danube region countries
column3: is logically connected to Vukovar as a centre of the Croatian part of the community of the Danube region. Cultural influences have always spread along the Danube. Since the Vukovar film festival is the only film festival focused on this region
column4: on the international level it seeks to connect filmmakers from the Danube region countries
column5: whose film making industries are some of the most vital in the world.

column2: the Chapel of Saint Rok
column3: and the Church of Saint Filip and Jakov in Vukovar
column4: and it traditionally starts with a concert by the Zagreb Philharmonic Orchestra. The guests of the festival are solo performers and chamber ensembles from Croatia and Europe.

column1: The Vukovar Puppet Spring Festival was founded in 1996 as a national theatre conference. There are around 15 puppet theatres performing every year and in the five days of the festival they give around 100 performances in the towns and municipalities of Vukovarsko-Srijemska County. The centre of the festival is the town of Vukovar where 16 performances are played and where various workshops and an awards ceremony are held (for the award for life achievement in contribution to Croatian puppetry). The festival is held at the same time every year
column2: the week before the Holy Week before Easter. In 2011 there were 16 puppet theatres from Croatia and abroad (Pecs
column3: Mostar) that participated the festival.

column1: Saint Vinko's Day in Vučedol is an event held traditionally every year on 22 January at the Goldschmidt farm grounds. This event marks the beginning of the year's work in the vineyards and it starts with a blessing of the vineyards. Sausages and other cured meat products are hung on the vines
column2: because of a tradition that by hanging large sausages on the vines
column3: the grape vines will be more fruitful and the grape clusters will be large. The same legend claims that if on that day
column4: before noon
column5: icicles or snow melts and creates puddles in which a sparrow can bathe
column6: the year will be fruitful and there will be so much wine that people can bathe in it. Along with an accompanying culture and art programme
column7: this event represents a true vineyard experience
column8: with mulled wine and delicacies that the visitors may taste or prepare for themselves

column1: Bonofest is held every year in the middle of May. It is a festival of spiritual music held in the church of Saint Filip and Jakov. The two evenings of the festival feature famous musicians as well as lesser known young musicians who were selected by a committee of professionals. Aside from showing the beauty and richness of spiritual music it encourages lyricists and composers to write new material and carries the message about the beauty of faith and the human need for spirituality.
The Ethno fair is organised each year by the Vukovar City Tourist Board and takes place in September in the city centre in the "Hotel Grand" building. Various craftsmen
column2: winemakers and other manufacturers sell their handmade products which represent the heritage of this part of Croatia.

column1: The Vukovar Advent Festivities start four weeks during Advent during which a series of musical and performance events are organised. Each event is special as the traditional lighting of the candles is performed.
Silent night in Vukovar is a traditional Christmas concert of Croatian National Television. It is held during Vukovar's Advent Festivities in the Church of St. Philip and James
The Christmas Fair is held a couple of days before Christmas.

column1: Vukovar is located in the northeastern part of the Republic of Croatia (45 ° 20 'north latitude and 16 ° 40' east longitude) and is the seat of the Vukovar-Srijem County.
